paper.title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

core_question: Can intratumoral mRNA vaccination create an interferon-rich tumor state that improves sensitivity to anti-PD-L1 immune checkpoint blockade?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse efficacy cohort (combination therapy)
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Pooled repeat-experiment mouse cohort used to evaluate intratumoral mRNA vaccine with anti-PD-L1 combination efficacy.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse matched control cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Matched mouse controls covering vaccine-only, ICI-only, and vehicle conditions for comparison against combination therapy effects.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human retrospective metastatic cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Retrospective cohort of metastatic patients receiving ICI treatment and stratified by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human vaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Subset of the retrospective metastatic cohort with prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination before or around ICI treatment.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human unvaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Subset of the retrospective metastatic cohort without prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination, used as comparator for outcomes under ICI.

major_limitations: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized, so residual confounding is likely.
Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients.
Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation.
Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.
Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.
